 Actually I like the concept. One thing you fail to note is that the RNA you refer to is actually transcripts from non-protein coding DNA - perhaps from what has been considered junk DNA in part. That of course is the first step by which protein coding genes function and the messenger RNA serves as the template for translation into polypeptides by ribosomes. There has never been any necessity that proteins are the only product derived from DNA sequences. Indeed one of the best contenders for early life forms has and so far as I know is the RNA world concept in which RNA was the original core structure and DNA only arose later on. In part this idea is supported by the retroviruses which carry their genes around in the form of RNA and generate transcripts suitable for DNA based life using a viral reverse transcriptase.
 
 Given the ability of RNA and DNA to interact and the possibility of modulation the expression of the RNA transcripts (and their fairly high rate of turnover) RNA is a good candidate as a control signal for the expression of other genes either in groups or singularly. The two structures are capable of exhibiting very selective interactions and this means that transmitters of signals can selectively be read by recipients by tuning the sequence of what amounts to the "messenger" RNA - why should the organism take the energy penalty of making a protein from the RNA to do the same - protein synthesis is quite expensive energetically. Indeed making protein requires the synthesis of transfer RNAs - a different one for each amino acid which carries a complemetary triplet sequence for recognition by messanger RNA as well as a means of activating a bound amino acid. 
 
 I would also point out that ribozymes have long been studied. These are RNA sequences which exhibit enzymatic properties. Again such structures may be older mechanisms than protein based catalysts.
 
 And of course the term "junk" has always been a placeholder label for DNA whose function is not known. That does not imply its not knowable and it never has. Its good to see progress being made with regard to its role in biology.
 
 In summary I welcome these findings as they expand our knowledge of the systems and mechanisms which lie at the core of our own existence as organisms.
